title-group.article-title: Lone Mothers, Family Credit and Paid Work

More formally, virtually all single parents in our sample were found to satisfy the Slutsky concavity condition. In other words, single parents were modelled to behave in a manner almost universally consistent with economic theory.

A 'probit' analysis is favoured here. The probit technique looks at the statistical relationship between an unohservable dependent variable (in this case, the probability of participation) and a series of observable variables (independent variables) assumed to have some bearing on the participation probability. The precise specification of the probit equation is unavoidably a matter of subjective choice, but variables are included with some prior economic interpretation. Table A1 of the Data Appendix reports econometric estimates of our participation probit. A 't-statistic' of around 2 or over indicates that the associated variable has a statistically significant impact on participation.

In the participation probit, the presence of the single parent's mother in the household was included in order to capture the availability of informal childcare. Formal childcare provision was proxied by the regional density of full day-care places (see Table Al, Data Appendix). The parameters of both variables are strong and positive. Moreover, even with the inclusion of variables to capture both regional differences and time variation, the formal childcare parameter returns a near-significant value.
Calculations are based on the participation probit equation presented in the Data Appendix.

There is a question of causality here. Some single mothers choose to work because their parents are able to look after the children. However, some single parents may choose to move in with (or stay with) their parents precisely because they work. Which is cause and which is effect is not clear.

The model used is a variant of the 'semi-log supply' function, and takes the form h = a+ ß In w + y (t/vv where h represents hours of work, w is the marginal wage and p denotes the unearned income of the household. Parameters a, ß and yean be varied to reflect demographic heterogeneity. The model is an attractive one for simulation since the indirect utility function can be explicitly derived. Thus it is relatively simple to carry out utility comparisons across different segments of a household budget constraint in order to estimate the most preferred choice of hours.

This is not an uncommon feature in estimates of the labour supply behaviour of single parents. Some lone mothers place a high valuation on their non-work time, given the range of commitments away from the workplace. They seek to attain a certain standard of living with the minimum amount of time at work. Given an increase in the marginal wage rate, it may suit such households to reduce labour supply (maintaining earned income at current levels) rather than to increase their labour supply to take advantage of the wage rise. In other words, some single parents value an extra hour of non-work time more highly than an extra hour's wages. This is an important point for policy-makers to recognise, and shows that work incentive effects from changing the tax-benefit system can be positive or negative.

As with most simulation procedures, we compare preferred hours (rather than actual hours) under the base tax system with preferred hours under the reform. Given the random preference structure of our model, actual and preferred hours can diverge quite markedly during simulation. This divergence is due mainly to the measurement and optimisation errors associated with hours and wages in our sample. We may not observe people to work exactly the number of hours they want for a number of reasons (misreporting, institutional constraints). However, with the random preference interpretation, all individuals are assumed to work their preferred number of hours. Clearly, this is an issue which must be addressed in future work.
